title: What can you learn from ancient poop?

multiple-choice.question: What can fossilized poop, also known as coprolites, tell us about ancient humans?

options.label: A
options.text: Only what they ate

options.label: B
options.text: Only where they lived

options.label: C
options.text: What they ate, where they lived, and how they died

options.label: D
options.text: Only how they died

options.label: A
options.text: Because ancient humans did not produce much poop

options.label: B
options.text: Because feces are tough to preserve

options.label: C
options.text: Because archaeologists do not know where to look for them

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not important to archaeologists

multiple-choice.question: How can poop be preserved for posterity?

options.label: A
options.text: Only by drying out in caves or in a mummy's desiccated intestines

options.label: B
options.text: Only by leaving dents in the earth that get filled in, creating a cast and mold of the ancient bowel movement

options.label: C
options.text: Only by turning to stone when minerals in water slowly permeate and replace the molecules in the turd

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What was discovered in a nearly 8-inch, 1000-year-old Viking coprolite found in England?

options.label: A
options.text: A large amount of undigested food

options.label: B
options.text: A high concentration of nutrients

options.label: C
options.text: Tons of intestinal parasites like whipworms

options.label: D
options.text: A unique type of bacteria

multiple-choice.question: What can the contents of coprolites tell us about ancient populations?

options.label: A
options.text: Only their diet

options.label: B
options.text: Only their cultural practices

options.label: C
options.text: Their diet, cultural practices, and parasites

options.label: D
options.text: Only their parasites

multiple-choice.question: How did fossilized turds help solve an ancient murder mystery in Medieval Verona?

options.label: A
options.text: By revealing the identity of the killer

options.label: B
options.text: By showing that the victim had ingested a poisonous plant before he died

options.label: C
options.text: By providing evidence of a struggle

options.label: D
options.text: By revealing the motive behind the murder

multiple-choice.question: What was found in the feces of Cangrande della Scala, the warlord of Medieval Verona?

options.label: A
options.text: Only chamomile pollen

options.label: B
options.text: Only mulberry pollen

options.label: C
options.text: Chamomile and mulberry pollen, as well as evidence of a poisonous plant

options.label: D
options.text: Only evidence of a poisonous plant

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about the death of Cangrande della Scala based on the analysis of his feces?

options.label: A
options.text: That he died of natural causes

options.label: B
options.text: That he was poisoned

options.label: C
options.text: That he died in battle

options.label: D
options.text: That he died of a disease

multiple-choice.question: Why is the study of coprolites important to archaeologists?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it provides a unique window into the daily lives of ancient humans

options.label: B
options.text: Because it allows them to reconstruct ancient diets

options.label: C
options.text: Because it helps them understand ancient cultural practices

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: That poop is a waste product that has no value

options.label: B
options.text: That coprolites can provide valuable insights into the lives of ancient humans

options.label: C
options.text: That archaeologists should focus on studying other types of fossils

options.label: D
options.text: That the study of coprolites is a new field of research
